message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hundreds of adenomatous polyps and a family history of colon cancer, which suggests a high risk for developing cancer. The most appropriate next step is surgical management with a proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis to reduce the risk of colon cancer development. Repeating colonoscopy in 6 months or endoscopic biopsy of polyps is not appropriate because of the large number of polyps present. Folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil, and oxaliplatin therapy are used to treat colon cancer but not recommended as a prophylactic measure.

Folinic acid + 5-fluorouracil + oxaliplatin therapy is used in colon cancer treatment, but not in prevention or management of familial adenomatous polyposis.

Proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis is the recommended surgical treatment for familial adenomatous polyposis to prevent the development of colon cancer. Repeat colonoscopy in 6 months or endoscopic biopsy of polyps will not address the underlying issue, and chemotherapy is not a first-line treatment for familial adenomatous polyposis.

With diffuse adenomatous polyps covering the colon and > 30 rectal adenomas, the most appropriate next step in management is proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis, as there are too many polyps to be endoscopically removed and the risk for colon cancer is high.
